snippet: Gu Kailai, a lawyer, spent more than two decades turning the government posts of her husband, Bo Xilai, into lucrative business opportunities.
abstract: Scandal involving the death of British businessman Neil Heywood in China appears to be evolving into a broader investigation into the wealth and financial interests of politically powerful Chinese couple Bo Xilai and his wife Gu Kailai; analysts say Communist Party leaders, by moving decisively against Gu and Bo, are trying to send a message to allies of Bo, who are still putting up resistance.

headline.main: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couple’s Wealth on Trial
headline.print_headline: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couple’s Wealth on Trial

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS and MICHAEL WINES

snippet: China intensified a propaganda campaign to paper over a split in the Communist Party as hints emerged of the wealth amassed by relatives of Bo Xilai, a deposed official.

headline.main: Chinese Media Fight Scandal Fallout; Focus on Bo’s Family
headline.print_headline: Chinese Image-Makers Race to Contain Scandal

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and KEITH BRADSHER

snippet: If e-book prices plummet as a result of the lawsuit by the Justice Department, the financial impact on Apple will likely be small, analysts say.
abstract: If e-book prices plummet as a result of the lawsuit by the Justice Department, the financial impact on Apple will likely be small, analysts say.

headline.main: Apple Not Likely to Be a Loser in the E-Book Legal Fight
headline.print_headline: E-Book Strategy Fails for Apple, To Little Effect

snippet: After months of negotiations, labels, music publishers and digital-media services said they had reached an agreement over publishing royalties for a range of new services. Also, Pandora explains how it matches music.
abstract: After months of negotiations, labels, music publishers and digital-media services said they had reached an agreement over publishing royalties for a range of new services. Also, Pandora explains how it matches music.

headline.main: Digital Notes: Updating Digital Royalties, and a Peek Under Pandora's Hood

snippet: David Pogue expresses his thoughts on the flurry of tech news of the past week, from Facebook’s deal for Instagram to an actual Mac virus
abstract: David Pogue expresses his thoughts on the flurry of tech news of the past week, from Facebook’s deal for Instagram to an actual Mac virus

headline.main: There Is a Lot of Big Tech News

snippet: Also, the new chief executive of Sony promises "difficult decisions" to revive the company, and Ann Romney starts a Twitter account to respond to comments from a Democratic strategist.
abstract: Also, the new chief executive of Sony promises "difficult decisions" to revive the company, and Ann Romney starts a Twitter account to respond to comments from a Democratic strategist.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Scrutiny for E-Book Pricing, and Phone-Hacking Lawsuits in U.S.

snippet: He has spent 36 years and 3,388 pages telling the story of Lyndon Johnson. He is nowhere near done.
Apple’s former patent chief, Richard Lutton Jr., has joined Nest Labs, a hot Silicon Valley start-up, which has developed a sleek, energy-saving digital thermostat.
abstract: Apple’s former patent chief, Richard Lutton Jr., has joined Nest Labs, a hot Silicon Valley start-up, which has developed a sleek, energy-saving digital thermostat.

headline.main: Apple's Former Patent Chief Joins Nest Labs

snippet: The government's decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon.com in a powerful position, David Streitfeld reports in Thursday's New York Times. The nation's largest bookseller may now get to decide...
abstract: The government's decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon.com in a powerful position, David Streitfeld reports in Thursday's New York Times. The nation's largest bookseller may now get to decide how much an e-book will cost, and the book world is quaking over the potential consequences.

headline.main: Daily Report: Amazon Set to Shake Industry by Cutting E-Book Prices

snippet: Kazuo Hirai said he would focus Sony’s resources away from its unprofitable television business and more toward mobile devices, cameras and games.
abstract: Sony chief executive Kazuo Hirai details company's turnaround plan, saying focus will shift resources away from the unprofitable television business and toward mobile devices, cameras and games; plan also includes cutting 10,000 jobs; Sony has had four consecutive years of losses, but has rapidly lost ground to other companies.

headline.main: Sony Chief Unveils Plans to Revive Company
headline.print_headline: Sony’s New Chief Lays Out a Plan for a Turnaround

byline.original: By HIROKO TABUCHI and BETTINA WASSENER
